pageTitle: Kathleen Barry - GoColumbiaLions.comOfficial Web Site of Columbia University Athletics
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {9343=2008-09: Named to CoSIDA/ESPN The Magazine Academic All-District I Second Team ... Academic All-Ivy League ... made first career start vs. Cal State Fullerton, scoring six points including game-winning bucket with 2.4 seconds remaining ... broke out for career-high 23 points on 9-of-12 shooting at Longwood, setting career marks in six different categories ... had team-high 14 points in career-high 32 minutes in Ivy League opener against Cornell ... perfect shooting night against Penn (6-6 FG, 2-2 FT) led to 15 points in win ... had two three-pointers in both games against Dartmouth ... scored 16 points and grabbed four rebounds in win over Brown ... tied career high with four steals in win over St. Francis (N.Y.). 2007-08: Scored 13 points on 5-for-7 shooting with two assists at Harvard ... topped that with career-best 14 points in 74-57 win vs. Princeton a week later ... also  had career-high four steals vs. Princeton ... scored four points in collegiate debut vs. Oakland ... career-high six points in 19 minutes in a 65-62 win vs. Lafayette ... hit pair of clutch free throws in overtime to help defeat Brown at home ... had four points in eight minutes vs. 16th-ranked West Virginia ... had three points and two rebounds in 17 minutes at Northern Colorado. The Bishop’s School: Two-time Coastal League Player of the Year ... first team All-San Diego County as a senior ... captain as a senior ... averaged 24 points per game as a senior ... four-year letterwinner ... also competed in track and cross country ... played for Team X in summer league. Personal: Economics/mathematics and spanish major ... formerly Kathleen Roehrkasse ... b. December 28, 1988 in Oceanside, Calif., 11704=2010-11: First team All-Ivy League selection ... became first player in Columbia women's basketball history to be named to CoSIDA/Capital One Academic All-America first team ... Academic All-Ivy League selection ... led team in scoring (10.4 PPG), rebounding (7.1 RPG) and steals (55) ... rebounding mark ranked second in the Ivy League ... scored in double-figures 17 times, including a streak of five straight at start of Ivy League season ... notched double-double, her seventh of the season, with 13 points and 10 rebounds in final career game against Brown ...  14 points and career-best 15 boards at Cornell ... had 13 points and nine rebounds against St. Francis (N.Y.) ... had double-double with 14 points and 11 boards, to go along with career-high four blocks against Cornell ... registered nine points and eight rebounds against Fairfield ... team-best 18 points on 8-of-12 shooting and added career-high four assists at Monmouth ... had 16 points and 14 rebounds against Wagner ... 12 points and seven rebounds against San Diego ... recorded first double-double of career with 14 points and 10 boards at Manhattan ... tallied 18 points and six rebounds vs. Fairleigh Dickinson ... scored 10 points and blocked a pair of shots in season opener against Long Island., 10391=2009-10: Honorable mention All-Ivy League ... named CoSIDA/ESPN The Magazine Academic All-District I First Team ... Academic All-Ivy League ... stepped into starting role and flourished, setting career marks for all major statistical categories ... started 25 games while battling hand and knee injuries for the majority of the season ... boosted her scoring average to 10.8 ppg to rank 11th in the Ivy League ... closed fifth in the conference in steals at 1.9 per game ... also finished fifth in three-point field goal percentage at 40.9 percent ... 14th in the conference in rebounding at 5.3 rpg ... scored double figures in 12 games, including 15 or more points seven times ... had 18 points in win over Delaware and narrow loss at N.C. State ... recorded 17 points in wins at Cornell and at Dartmouth ... grabbed 10 rebounds in victory over Long Island and also in loss on road to Harvard ... had stretch of five games where she recorded multiple steals, including five in both games against Cornell.}
